title: Task 3.2: Offline-first data layer with CacheStrategy
description:
Task 3.2 from PRD Phase 3: Architecture Modernization

Implement generic CachePolicy abstraction with per-repository strategies.

CacheStrategy enum: cacheFirst, networkFirst, cacheOnly, networkOnly, staleWhileRevalidate.

Per-repository strategy:
- ServerRepository: staleWhileRevalidate (5 min TTL)
- SubscriptionRepository: cacheFirst (1 hour TTL)
- AuthRepository (user profile): cacheFirst (24 hours TTL)
- ReferralRepository: networkFirst (15 min TTL)
- SettingsRepository: cacheOnly (local)

## Files Affected
- All repository implementations

## Issues Addressed
- M8: No offline-first data layer

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] CacheStrategy enum created with 5 strategies
- [ ] Generic CachePolicy<T> abstraction created
- [ ] Each repository configured with appropriate cache strategy and TTL
- [ ] Server list available offline with stale-while-revalidate pattern
- [ ] User profile cached for 24 hours
- [ ] Settings work fully offline
- [ ] Network-first repositories fall back to cache on failure
- [ ] Cache entries expire based on configured TTL

## Quality Gates
- [ ] `flutter analyze` passes for all modified files
- [ ] Offline behavior tested (airplane mode returns cached data)
close_reason: Offline-first CacheStrategy completed: enum, mixin, applied to ServerRepo (SWR), SubscriptionRepo (cacheFirst), ReferralRepo (networkFirst), AuthRepo (already cache-first)

title: Task 3.6: WebSocket jitter for backoff
description:
Task 3.6 from PRD Phase 3: Architecture Modernization

Add randomized jitter to WebSocketClient._calculateBackoff() to prevent thundering herd on server restart.

Implementation:
  Duration _calculateBackoff() {
    final baseSeconds = _initialBackoff.inSeconds *
        math.pow(_backoffMultiplier, _reconnectAttempt).toInt();
    final capped = math.min(baseSeconds, _maxBackoff.inSeconds);
    final jitter = Random().nextInt(capped ~/ 2 + 1); // 0..50% of delay
    return Duration(seconds: capped + jitter);
  }

## Files Affected
- `lib/core/network/websocket_client.dart`

## Issues Addressed
- M11: WebSocket reconnection without jitter

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] _calculateBackoff() includes randomized jitter (0-50% of capped delay)
- [ ] Pure exponential backoff replaced with jittered backoff
- [ ] Current backoff caps preserved (1s, 2s, 4s, 8s, 16s, 30s base)
- [ ] Jitter prevents synchronized reconnection from all clients
- [ ] Random import added from dart:math

## Quality Gates
- [ ] `flutter analyze` passes for websocket_client.dart

CRITICAL (C-1.1): Biometric login stores user password in plaintext JSON within SecureStorage. If device is compromised (rooted, backup extraction, malware), the password is exposed directly.

## Files
- lib/core/storage/secure_storage.dart:265-296 — stores {email, password} as JSON
- lib/features/auth/presentation/providers/biometric_login_provider.dart:196-199 — replays password

## Remediation
1. Implement device-bound token authentication flow:
   - On biometric enrollment: call POST /mobile/auth/biometric/enroll -> receive device token
   - Store device token (not password) in SecureStorage
   - On biometric login: send device token to POST /mobile/auth/biometric/login
2. Add migration function migrateCredentialFormat() that:
   - Reads existing plaintext credentials
   - Enrolls device token with backend
   - Replaces plaintext credentials with device token
   - Deletes old biometricCredentialsKey
3. Call migration on app startup (idempotent)
4. Remove deprecated setBiometricCredentials() / getBiometricCredentials() methods
5. Make _setBiometricCredentialsDeprecated private immediately

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] No plaintext passwords stored anywhere in SecureStorage
- [ ] Biometric login uses device-bound token
- [ ] Migration function converts existing users
- [ ] Old methods throw UnsupportedError or are removed
- [ ] flutter analyze passes
- [ ] flutter test passes
close_reason: All subtasks complete: device-bound token auth implemented

title: Clear SecureStorage in-memory cache on logout
description:
CRITICAL (H-3.2): The in-memory _cache map in SecureStorageWrapper retains tokens after clearAll(). A memory dump post-logout would reveal the previous user's tokens.

## Remediation
1. Add invalidateCache() call at the start of clearAll():
   Future<void> clearAll() async {
     invalidateCache();  // Clear memory first
     final deviceId = await read(key: deviceIdKey);
     // ... existing deletion logic
   }
2. Also clear AppLogger ring buffer on logout:
   AppLogger.clearLogs();  // Prevent log-based PII leakage
3. Verify _clearAuthTokens() in LogoutNotifier also invalidates cache

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] clearAll() calls invalidateCache() before storage operations
- [ ] AppLogger buffer cleared on logout
- [ ] Unit test verifies cache is empty after clearAll()
- [ ] flutter analyze passes
- [ ] flutter test passes

title: SEC-001: Encrypt TOTP secrets in database
description:
**Severity:** HIGH  
**Category:** A07: Authentication Failures  
**Affected File:** `/home/beep/projects/VPNBussiness/backend/src/infrastructure/database/models/admin_user_model.py:41`

## Problem
TOTP secrets are stored in plaintext in the database. While `.env.example` documents `TOTP_ENCRYPTION_KEY` for encryption, the actual model and TOTP service do not implement encryption.

```python
totp_secret: Mapped[Optional[str]] = mapped_column(String(32), nullable=True)
```

## Risk
If the database is compromised, attackers can extract TOTP secrets and bypass 2FA for all users.

## Remediation
1. Encrypt TOTP secrets using AES-256-GCM with the `TOTP_ENCRYPTION_KEY`
2. Implement decrypt-on-read, encrypt-on-write in the TOTP service
3. Add migration to encrypt existing plaintext secrets

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] TOTP secrets are encrypted at rest using AES-256-GCM
- [ ] `TOTP_ENCRYPTION_KEY` from environment is used for encryption
- [ ] Decrypt-on-read logic in TOTP service works correctly
- [ ] Encrypt-on-write logic in TOTP service works correctly
- [ ] Migration exists to encrypt existing plaintext secrets
- [ ] Unit tests verify encryption/decryption round-trip

## References
- CWE-311 (Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data)
- OWASP A02:2025

MAX_TOKENS_PER_USER = 10  # Limit concurrent sessions

title: SEC-002: Add non-root user to Docker container
description:
**Severity:** HIGH  
**Category:** A05: Security Misconfiguration  
**Affected File:** `/home/beep/projects/VPNBussiness/backend/Dockerfile:1-16`

## Problem
The Dockerfile does not specify a non-root user, meaning the application runs as root inside the container.

```dockerfile
FROM python:3.13-slim
WORKDIR /app
# ... no USER directive
CMD ["uvicorn", "src.main:app", "--host", "0.0.0.0", "--port", "8000"]
```

## Risk
Container escape vulnerabilities or application compromises can lead to host system access with root privileges.

## Remediation
```dockerfile
FROM python:3.13-slim

# Create non-root user
RUN groupadd -r cybervpn && useradd -r -g cybervpn cybervpn

WORKDIR /app
COPY --chown=cybervpn:cybervpn pyproject.toml ./
RUN pip install --no-cache-dir -e .
COPY --chown=cybervpn:cybervpn . .

USER cybervpn
EXPOSE 8000
CMD ["uvicorn", "src.main:app", "--host", "0.0.0.0", "--port", "8000"]
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Dockerfile creates a non-root user `cybervpn`
- [ ] Application files are owned by non-root user
- [ ] `USER cybervpn` directive is present before CMD
- [ ] Container starts successfully with non-root user
- [ ] Application functions correctly (health check passes)

## References
- CWE-250 (Execution with Unnecessary Privileges)
- OWASP A05:2025
close_reason: Closed

title: SEC-003: Implement JWT revocation check in auth dependency
description:
**Severity:** MEDIUM  
**Category:** A07: Authentication Failures  
**Affected File:** `/home/beep/projects/VPNBussiness/backend/src/presentation/dependencies/auth.py:22-30`

## Problem
The `get_current_user` dependency decodes JWT tokens but does not check the revocation list implemented in `JWTRevocationService`.

```python
async def get_current_user(...):
    try:
        payload = auth_service.decode_token(credentials.credentials)
        # No revocation check: await revocation_service.is_revoked(payload.get("jti"))
        ...
```

## Risk
Revoked tokens (from logout or logout-all) remain valid until expiration, defeating the purpose of token revocation.

1. Inject Redis client into the auth dependency
2. Check `JWTRevocationService.is_revoked(jti)` before returning the user
3. Return 401 if token is revoked

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Auth dependency injects Redis client
- [ ] `is_revoked(jti)` check added before returning user
- [ ] Revoked tokens return 401 Unauthorized
- [ ] Non-revoked tokens continue to work normally
- [ ] Unit tests verify revoked token rejection
- [ ] Integration test: logout invalidates token immediately

## References
- CWE-613 (Insufficient Session Expiration)
- OWASP A07:2025
close_reason: JWT revocation check implemented in get_current_user auth dependency

Fix critical bugs in the Onboarding module of cybervpn_mobile.

title: Task 1: Fix Router Loading State
description:
Add shouldShowOnboardingProvider.isLoading check in app_router.dart redirect to prevent race condition during app startup.

**File:** lib/app/router/app_router.dart

**Problem:** The redirect function only checks isAuthLoading. The shouldShowOnboardingProvider is a FutureProvider that may still be Loading when the router initializes. When loading, .value returns null which defaults to false, causing the router to skip onboarding incorrectly.

**Fix:** Add a check for ref.read(shouldShowOnboardingProvider).isLoading at the beginning of the redirect function. If isLoading is true, return null (stay on Splash) — same pattern as the existing isAuthLoading check.

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] In app_router.dart redirect function, add check: if shouldShowOnboardingProvider.isLoading == true, return null
- [ ] The isLoading check is placed before any onboarding routing logic
- [ ] On clean app launch (cleared data), Splash Screen stays visible until both auth and onboarding providers finish loading, then automatically transitions to Onboarding
- [ ] No UI glitch or flicker between Splash and Onboarding screens

## Quality Gates
- [ ] flutter analyze passes with no errors
- [ ] flutter test passes (if tests exist for router)
- [ ] App launches and transitions from Splash to Onboarding without user interaction
close_reason: Added isOnboardingLoading check in splash guard. Splash now waits for both auth AND onboarding providers before redirecting.

title: Task 2: Fix Provider Invalidation
description:
Add ref.invalidate(shouldShowOnboardingProvider) in onboarding_provider.dart skip() and complete() methods to fix stale cached state.

**File:** lib/features/onboarding/presentation/providers/onboarding_provider.dart

**Problem:** When the user presses Skip or Get Started, OnboardingNotifier updates the repository (isComplete = true) but does NOT invalidate shouldShowOnboardingProvider. The router guard still reads the cached true value and redirects back to /onboarding, creating a navigation loop.

**Fix:** In both skip() and complete() methods of OnboardingNotifier, add ref.invalidate(shouldShowOnboardingProvider) after the repository call succeeds. This forces the FutureProvider to re-fetch from the repository, get the updated false value, and allow the router to navigate away from onboarding.

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] In OnboardingNotifier.skip(), ref.invalidate(shouldShowOnboardingProvider) is called after successful repository update
- [ ] In OnboardingNotifier.complete(), ref.invalidate(shouldShowOnboardingProvider) is called after successful repository update
- [ ] Pressing "Skip" on the Onboarding screen navigates to /permissions (or the next logical screen) without being redirected back
- [ ] Pressing "Get Started" on the Onboarding screen navigates to /permissions without being redirected back
- [ ] On subsequent app launches after completing/skipping onboarding, the Onboarding screen is NOT shown

## Quality Gates
- [ ] flutter analyze passes with no errors
- [ ] flutter test passes
- [ ] Skip and Get Started buttons navigate correctly (manual verification)
close_reason: Added ref.invalidate(shouldShowOnboardingProvider) in both skip() and complete() methods.

**Fix:**
1. Use PageController as the single source of truth for the current page index in UI
2. Simplify _onPageChanged: just update the page indicator index (via setState or a simple provider update) — remove the complex synchronization logic with nextPage/previousPage

- [ ] PageController is the single source of truth for the current page index
- [ ] _handleSkip is wrapped in try-catch with SnackBar error display

Current issue:
- Custom transitions in app_router.dart (lines 77-100) animate entire screen
- Causes full widget tree repaint on every transition frame
- Especially bad on low-end devices

Fix in _buildSlideTransition:
- Wrap the child parameter in RepaintBoundary before returning from SlideTransition
- Flutter will cache the child's paint output
- Only the transform layer animates, not the entire widget tree

Files:
- cybervpn_mobile/lib/app/router/app_router.dart (lines 77-100)

Example:
return SlideTransition(
  position: ...,
  child: RepaintBoundary(child: child),
);

Estimated: 15 minutes
close_reason: Wrapped route transition child in RepaintBoundary to isolate paint layer.

title: Mobile Quality Hardening & Performance Optimization
description:
Consolidates findings from 12 parallel expert analyses covering architecture, performance, security, UI/UX, testing, navigation, state management, networking, animations, i18n, Dart patterns, and general development practices.

Critical findings:
1. App freezes on splash screen due to missing Dio timeouts, endpoint path mismatch, and production StateError crash when certificate fingerprints are not configured.
2. Android release builds have broken plugin registration: build.gradle.kts excludes auto-generated GeneratedPluginRegistrant, stale manual fallback uses reflection that R8 strips, and google-services Gradle plugin is missing (Firebase fails to init).

Covers P0 (splash freeze, crash prevention, biometric API, Android plugin registration), P1 (networking, navigation, security, performance), P2 (architecture, testing, i18n), and P3 (UI/UX polish, animation refinements).

Source: cybervpn_mobile/docs/mobile/PRD_MOBILE_HARDENING.md

title: P0: Splash Screen Freeze Fix (Dio Timeouts + Endpoint Path + NetworkInfo Timeout)
description:
Fix the 3 root causes of splash screen freeze: missing Dio timeouts, endpoint path mismatch, and connectivity_plus hang.

## Changes Required

### 1.1 Configure Dio Timeouts (RC-1)
File: lib/core/di/providers.dart:501
Replace `final dio = Dio();` with:
```dart
final dio = Dio(BaseOptions(
  connectTimeout: const Duration(seconds: 10),
  receiveTimeout: const Duration(seconds: 15),
  sendTimeout: const Duration(seconds: 10),
));
```

### 1.2 Fix Endpoint Path Mismatch (RC-2)
File: lib/features/auth/data/datasources/auth_remote_ds.dart:34
Replace hardcoded `_basePath = '/mobile/auth'` with ApiConstants paths.
The backend expects `/api/v1/auth/me`, not `/mobile/auth/me`.

### 1.3 Add Timeout to NetworkInfo.isConnected (RC-3)
File: lib/core/network/network_info.dart:8-10
Wrap `checkConnectivity()` in `.timeout(Duration(seconds: 2))`.
Return true on timeout (assume connected; let HTTP determine reality).

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Dio has connectTimeout=10s, receiveTimeout=15s, sendTimeout=10s
- [ ] Auth remote data source uses ApiConstants paths instead of hardcoded /mobile/auth
- [ ] NetworkInfo.isConnected has 2-second timeout and returns true on timeout
- [ ] App launches to login screen within 3 seconds on airplane mode
- [ ] No splash freeze on slow networks or captive portals
- [ ] flutter analyze passes with no errors

title: P1.2: Add missing persistence for 5 settings fields
description:
Add SharedPreferences persistence for 5 `AppSettings` fields that currently reset to defaults
on every app restart: oledMode, scanlineEffect, textScale, hapticsEnabled, trustedWifiNetworks.

Fixes BUG-6 (5 AppSettings fields not persisted).

## Implementation

In `lib/features/settings/data/repositories/settings_repository_impl.dart`:

1. Add key constants:
   - `static const _kOledMode = 'settings.oledMode';`
   - `static const _kScanlineEffect = 'settings.scanlineEffect';`
   - `static const _kTextScale = 'settings.textScale';`
   - `static const _kHapticsEnabled = 'settings.hapticsEnabled';`
   - `static const _kTrustedWifiNetworks = 'settings.trustedWifiNetworks';`

2. Add these keys to `_allKeys` list

3. In `getSettings()`, read these values:
   - `oledMode`: `_prefs.getBool(_kOledMode) ?? false`
   - `scanlineEffect`: `_prefs.getBool(_kScanlineEffect) ?? true`

title: MED-003: Token Return Type Handling
description:
As a backend developer, I need to fix the token creation return type handling to prevent runtime type errors and enable proper JTI tracking for token revocation.

## Current State

```python
# backend/src/application/use_cases/auth/login.py:68-72
access_token = self._auth_service.create_access_token(  # Returns tuple!
    subject=str(user.id),
    role=user.role,
)
refresh_token = self._auth_service.create_refresh_token(subject=str(user.id))  # Returns tuple!
```

The `create_access_token` and `create_refresh_token` methods return tuples `(token, jti, expire)` but the code treats them as strings.

## Target State

- Proper tuple unpacking for token creation
- JTI values stored for revocation support
- No runtime type errors in auth flows

## Implementation

**File**: `backend/src/application/use_cases/auth/login.py`

```python
# Unpack token tuple: (token, jti, expire)
access_token, access_jti, access_expire = self._auth_service.create_access_token(
    subject=str(user.id),
    role=user.role,
)

refresh_token, refresh_jti, refresh_expire = self._auth_service.create_refresh_token(
    subject=str(user.id)
)

# Register tokens for revocation tracking
await self._revocation_service.register_token(
    user_id=str(user.id),
    jti=access_jti,
    token_type="access",
    expires_at=access_expire,
)
```

- [ ] `create_refresh_token` returns tuple properly unpacked

title: LOW-002: Async Sleep in Auth Route
description:
As a backend developer, I need to replace blocking time.sleep() with async asyncio.sleep() in the auth route to prevent event loop blocking under concurrent load.

## Current State

```python
# backend/src/presentation/api/v1/auth/routes.py:113
if elapsed < min_response_time:
    time.sleep(min_response_time - elapsed + secrets.randbelow(50) / 1000)
```

The blocking `time.sleep()` call freezes the entire event loop during timing normalization, causing degraded performance under concurrent load.

## Target State

- Use `asyncio.sleep()` for non-blocking timing normalization
- No event loop blocking under concurrent load

## Implementation

**File**: `backend/src/presentation/api/v1/auth/routes.py`

```python
import asyncio
import secrets

async def normalize_response_time(start_time: float, min_response_time: float = 0.3):
    """
    Normalize response time to prevent timing attacks.
    Uses async sleep to avoid blocking the event loop.
    """
    elapsed = time.monotonic() - start_time
    if elapsed < min_response_time:
        jitter = secrets.randbelow(50) / 1000  # 0-50ms random jitter
        await asyncio.sleep(min_response_time - elapsed + jitter)

@router.post("/login")
async def login(request: LoginRequest, ...):
    start_time = time.monotonic()
    try:
        # ... login logic ...
        return response
    finally:
        await normalize_response_time(start_time)
```

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] `asyncio.sleep()` used instead of `time.sleep()`
- [ ] No event loop blocking under concurrent load
- [ ] Response time normalization still works correctly (timing attack prevention)
- [ ] Random jitter still applied (0-50ms)

title: LOW-005: Request ID Propagation
description:
As an incident responder, I want every log entry to include a unique request ID so that I can correlate events during investigation.

## Current State

- Log correlation difficult
- Cannot trace requests across async operations

## Target State

- Every request has unique ID
- ID included in all logs and response headers
- ID propagated via context vars for async operations

## Implementation

**File**: `backend/src/presentation/middleware/request_id.py` (new file)

```python
import uuid
from contextvars import ContextVar
from starlette.middleware.base import BaseHTTPMiddleware

request_id_var: ContextVar[str] = ContextVar("request_id", default="")

def get_request_id() -> str:
    """Get the current request ID from context."""
    return request_id_var.get()

class RequestIDMiddleware(BaseHTTPMiddleware):
    HEADER_NAME = "X-Request-ID"

    async def dispatch(self, request: Request, call_next):
        request_id = request.headers.get(self.HEADER_NAME) or str(uuid.uuid4())
        token = request_id_var.set(request_id)
        try:
            response = await call_next(request)
            response.headers[self.HEADER_NAME] = request_id
            return response
        finally:
            request_id_var.reset(token)
```

title: LOW-001: HKDF Salt Documentation
description:
As a security auditor, I want the HKDF salt decision documented or improved so that the cryptographic design is properly justified.

## Current State

```python
hkdf = HKDF(
    algorithm=hashes.SHA256(),
    length=32,
    salt=None,  # No salt for deterministic derivation
    info=self.INFO_CONTEXT,
)
```

No salt is used in HKDF key derivation, which reduces protection against precomputation attacks.

## Options

### Option A: Add Random Salt (Recommended for v1.1)

```python
class TOTPEncryption:
    SALT_LENGTH = 16

    def encrypt(self, secret: str) -> str:
        salt = os.urandom(self.SALT_LENGTH)
        derived_key = self._derive_key(salt)
        fernet = Fernet(base64.urlsafe_b64encode(derived_key))
        encrypted = fernet.encrypt(secret.encode())
        # Prepend salt to encrypted data
        return base64.urlsafe_b64encode(salt + encrypted).decode()
```

Requires database migration for existing encrypted secrets.

### Option B: Document Current Approach (Recommended for v1.0)

Add code comment explaining the trade-off:
- Master key is high-entropy (256-bit random)

- Adding salt would require database migration

Implement unified logging across frontend, backend, and mobile with request correlation and error monitoring.

Backend has structlog (good). Frontend uses unstructured console.log. Mobile has inconsistent approaches. Need Sentry integration, request ID correlation, and Grafana dashboards.

Source: docs/PRD-improvements.md (DX-02)

title: DX-02.1: Integrate Sentry SDK in frontend
description:
Add Sentry SDK to the frontend for error tracking and performance monitoring.

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Sentry SDK installed and configured in the Next.js app
- [ ] Error boundary integration: errors captured automatically
- [ ] Performance monitoring enabled (page load, API calls)
- [ ] Source maps uploaded to Sentry for readable stack traces
- [ ] `npm run lint` passes
- [ ] `npm run build` passes

title: DX-02.1a: Integrate Sentry SDK in Next.js frontend
description: Install and configure Sentry SDK in Next.js app. Enable error boundary integration, performance monitoring, and source map uploads.

title: DX-02.2: Add request ID correlation across frontend and backend
description:
Implement request ID generation and propagation for cross-service log correlation.

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Backend generates unique request ID (UUID) for each request via middleware
- [ ] Request ID logged in all backend structlog entries
- [ ] Frontend sends request ID in `X-Request-ID` header for all API calls
- [ ] Backend returns request ID in response headers
- [ ] Frontend includes request ID in Sentry error context
- [ ] `pytest` passes
- [ ] `npm run build` passes

description: Create FastAPI middleware that generates UUID request IDs, logs them in structlog entries, and returns them in X-Request-ID response header.

description: Update frontend API client to generate and send X-Request-ID header on all requests. Include request ID in Sentry error context for correlation.

title: DX-02.3: Create Grafana dashboard for error monitoring
description:
Create a Grafana dashboard aggregating frontend and backend error metrics.

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Grafana dashboard provisioned in infra/docker-compose (monitoring profile)
- [ ] Dashboard panels: error rate (frontend + backend), response times, top errors
- [ ] Request ID searchable in logs for end-to-end tracing
- [ ] Dashboard accessible at the monitoring endpoint

title: Task 4.1: Fix plural forms -- ru, pl, uk, cs
description:
Task 4.1 from PRD Phase 4: Internationalization

Fix CLDR plural violations:
- ru: Replace =1{...} with one{...} in all 8 plural messages. Ensure few and many forms handle 2-4, 5-20, 21+ patterns.
- pl: Translate all 7 plural messages with proper one/few/many/other forms.
- uk: Translate all 7 plural messages with proper one/few/many/other forms.
- cs: Translate daysRemaining with proper one/few/many/other forms.

Russian fix example:
  BEFORE: "daysRemaining": "{count, plural, =1{...} few{...} many{...} other{...}}"
  AFTER:  "daysRemaining": "{count, plural, one{...} few{...} many{...} other{...}}"

The one{} CLDR category for Russian matches: 1, 21, 31, 41, 51, 61, etc. The =1{} exact match only matches 1.

## Files Affected
- `app_ru.arb`
- `app_pl.arb`
- `app_uk.arb`
- `app_cs.arb`
